comments.commentBody: I flew 130,000 miles last year.  I had items stolen out of check baggage locked with TSA "approved" locks twice within three weeks.  TSA said that since contractors checked the luggage it wasn't their fault and that I was free to file a lawsuit if I wished.  Nice, as long as something is less valuable than the price of a lawyer they are effectively free to steal it.

Comment #81, Ray said, "If you can't take it. Use Amtrak or Greyhound. Sheesh."

So I'm supposed to take the bus to Australia?
I wonder how much of this Michelle Bachmann knows about. She keeps saying she knows everything that goes on in Minnesota. Maybe the authorities should also talk to her.
We're all anonymous tonight?  (This is Wags, and I'll admit to be #4.)

JolleyGood says he initially had Sally Fields as the Forrest Gump co-star, but the crosses didn't work.  Of course, it is Sally Field (not Fields) that was a co-star, so she wouldn't fit at 33A even if the first five crosses worked.

He should hire me as head up his economic team. I'd start by telling him to let the Bush tax cuts expire, then veto any attempt to privatize social security, cut medicare, and so on.

But who cares what I think? I only worked my tail off to get Obama elected. Now that he's in office, why should he keep his campaign promises to his base?

My husband was having eyelid swelling with headaches for the past 6 weeks, and an MRI showed eye muscle swelling. He was diagnosed with Hashimoto Thyroidism, with a TSH number of 6 (just above normal). An ultrasound showed slight scarring of the thyroid. The endochronologist and optomologist think the eye muscle swelling is an atypical manifestation of Hashimotos and want to do an eye muscle biopsy to verify what is causing the swelling. It seems we have no choice and are concerned in the event it is due to something else that should be treated in a different way.  Your thoughts on the biopsy?
Surely you're joking, #61
Well, after all this, you know the terrorists are going to change targets, go for a bridge or two. Then what? Can you pat down a Civic?

Has anyone flown through Amsterdam or Frankfurt in the past year?  Everyone is patted down several times while going through these airports and I have been singled out  a number of times times for extra searches because of my UAE residency visa and name.  While unpleasant, I have just accepted this as a part of travel.  I am, however,  much more disturbed by the body scanners in the US airports and I plan to opt out and get patted down when I make a trip to the US next week.

A few random observations, after having flown throughout the US, Mexico, Canada, and France within the past year. The airport security experience varies tremendously within the US, and it doe not necessarily correlate that smaller airports function more efficiently. In fact, sometimes the checkers are overly zealous in small locations. Professional orchestra musicians travelling together are routinely subjected to intrusive and superfluous examination of their valuable instruments. Some checkers seem to delight in confiscating nail scissors and toothpaste. By comparison, security at CDG was a breeze--thorough, efficient, and remarkably pleasant. Plus, you don't have to remove your shoes.
Wow!  Another victory for the forces of freedom and liberty.  Please celebrate by participating in national Opt-Out Day...

Hans#14
Your formula looks like a good generalization for all values of f and s.
My observations were for these two particular cases. I will try to explain it.

In first case we have 5 stops and 10 floors .As you explain it, each floor needs to be on ceil[f-1]/[s-1] ie 3 elevator stops. So this means that from each floor there are 4*3=12 different ways or connections of getting out of that floor.(ie 12 combinations obtained by combining 4 destination floors and 3 different elevators). This gives a total of 12 * 10 =120 combinations for all the stops/floors.
We will half this number to get 60 connections (as I am treating connection from floor A to B and floor B to A as one connection.)
Each elevator with 5 stops provides us (5*4)/2 = 10 different connections.
Therefore 60 connections will require 6 floors.
Hope this explains my reasoning.

We can use a similar approach for the second case.
The second case is little tricky. An elevator with 6 stops provides 15 connections.
A floor needs to be on 2 elevators to cover the 9 connections it needs.(again ceil 9/6 =2 as per your formula.) If it is on 2 elevators the floor has in all 5 +5 =10 connections .So the total connections come out to be (10 * 10) /2 = 50 which will be covered by 4 elevators.(4 elevators will provide 60 connections whereas 3 will provide 45, so we choose 4)

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
Such fakery happens so often.

Do you remember the scene in "Good Will Hunting" where Will, played by Matt Damon, sent his friend (played by Ben Affleck) posing as Will to a job interview? The job was sewn up -- they wanted Will. So the friend just played them along till he could scoop up some cash, and left.

Think of "The Flim Flam Man," with George C. Scott as another rogue. But soon we're getting out of pure hustler country, and into the Afghanistan caper you cite today. Or we're into the caper set in motion by Mayor Bloomberg of NYC, naming a corporate executive with never any experience in public ed posing as her own form of imposter to take over all NYC public schools.

What we're talking about eventually isn't just ever new forms of Melville's "The Confidence Man," but only one caper -- the one where Corporate America imposes ever its demeaned, vulgarized, cynical, and anti-human agendas on all the world. Yes, we know the five male justices of the Supreme Court ruled big piles of money the highest law of the land. Yes, lots of us saw the Andy Martin piece on philosophers as often being male -- and autistic. Something about being male lends itself to lack of empathy -- to the most anti-human frauds and abstractions. Cathie Black can do it, too. Any of us can who enroll in any of the mass of biz and law schools set up to school this type.

Something about Corporate America eptitomizes the sheer helplessness of Americans abroad to deal with fake humanity -- or to recognize the real humans and humanity of traditional cultures that, for our most venal corporate interests, we demean and traduce over and over worldwide.

The list of people who are taking us for a ride is long. It includes not only the folks you mentioned, but also:

* military contractors like Haliburton

* private military forces run by companies like Blackwater (now known as Xe)

* former military officials who appear in the media as voices of wisdom on military policy, but who are actually doing the bidding of the private military companies by whom they are paid

* conservatives who gain their political power in part by keeping the American public fearful

* politicians who get large campaign contributions from military contractors

We really should put an end to these pointless military adventures that waste the lives of our young men and women in uniform, undermine our national security, and use up limited taxpayer money that could be used to stimulate the economy, help the unemployed, and reduce the deficit. Here's hoping that President Obama will put us on track toward an orderly end to operations in Afghanistan and help create a situation where the American people are no longer taken for a ride.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

It's hard to say what's more farcical, our war with people we can't recognize in a far-away land, or the TSA's degradation of Americans here at home. Obviously, more harm comes from the former, but more Americans are experiencing the latter.

Thank you for writing on a serious subject. The fact that this serious subject is playing out like a Billy Wilder comedy makes it no less serious, as American lives are lost & American dollars are wasted in pursuit of nothing.

If the protagonists in this tragicomedy are Obama & Petraeus, it is a drama that so far has lacked a chorus. The American people, out-of-work or underpaid, up till now have not even been watching the play. This week, most have been preoccupied with buying frozen birds and gaming out Black Friday, hoping they can stretch their meager holiday funds without getting trampled at Wal-Mart. But many of these same blase Americans will also be traveling this weekend, and they will find themselves suddenly slapped with their first uncomfortable encounter with the "war on terror." Fine, upstanding holiday travelers are going to be treated like criminals. It won't be Guantanamo, but it won't be pleasant, either.

The Congress won't put a stop to the war in Afghanistan. Even though it's already our longest war, the President is bent on extending it. If any good comes of the TSA super-rays & patdowns, perhaps it will be that a few more Americans will wake up and realize that these extraordinary invasions of privacy are part-and-parcel of our completely inept anti-terrorism strategy. The patdowns are no more effective at stopping terrorism than are negotiations with an impostor.

Let us hope the American people tell our leaders enough is enough. It's time to bring the troops home now. And all in one piece, please. Happy Thanksgiving.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

P.S. Anybody who still thinks the Afghanistan War is a good idea, please read Bob Wright's column on this same page.

Probably a dozen Hollywood treatments are already being spun together on this story. My favorite NYT story since the Wisconsin guy shot out his TV screen thinking he had Bristol Palin in his crosshairs.

Any report on what we agreed to with the imposter? Have we committed to withdrawing from the Afghanistanian mire earlier? Were we negotiating a power sharing deal beween the dread Karzai and the even dreader Mullah Omar. In all decency, whatever we had negotiated with the imposter, we should by all means stick to should the Taliban ever actually deign to send an authorized envoy. It is good to know that our incompetence extends beyond domestic affairs and matters of war to intelligence and diplomacy. We're terrific in all we do. Spreading our greatness from sea to shining sea.

American intelligence is an oxymoron. There's the proven stupidity of the American bigwigs who get played by Afghanistan and Pakistan, and there's the apparent stupidity of the American people who let themselves get played by the bigwigs.

While we are flying planeloads of cash to fill the coffers of the mentally ill Karzai, we're subjecting planeloads of ordinary Americans to draconian searches in the name of "safety". We are told to forgo our fourth amendment rights by our own president. Television pundits are unquestioning, and advise us not to rock the boat by protesting the aptly named "Rapi-scans" and enhanced feel-ups. It would inconvenience other people if we stand up for our rights, according to them.

Until more of us do rock the boat and throw a few monkey wrenches into the works, the Bill of Rights will be whittled away to nonexistence. We have to whittle away at the Great American Con. We have to demand an end to the War for Nothing. It's time to show them we are not stupid, and to cast off our sheep's clothing.

Homeland Security Chief Napolitano infamously boasted that the system worked after the Underwear Bomber takedown last Christmas. Her system did not work - ours did, because a citizen did what a slew of intelligence agencies (another oxymoron) could not. Why do they keep pretending the people are not on to them?

This is a minor blip in a largely unwinnable war. We all know why President Obama is sticking around - He does'nt want to appear weak to the American people. Let's be honest, and not pretend otherwise.

We all (and he) know that if he pulls out now he would be ridiculed as spineless. The lives saved will not be counted. The ridicule we as a nation endure with the likes of this imposter will never happen. What will be rememered is that "we left" when "we could have won".

Is this reason enough for us to stay, when we all know that we cannot win.

If U.S. military intelligence can't tell whether a man sitting at the negotiation table with top officials is even in the Taliban, what do you think is the accuracy of their reports that bombs actually killed Taliban officials, and not more, random "ghosts", er innocent civilians?
This is known as smart diplomacy.  It's time that we brought back cowboy diplomacy, which was more successful in meeting our interests.

What's a few trillion?

At least back home, billionaire Jamie Dimon is only evicting his fellow Americans who deserve it!

And people say America is a great country?

Velma Hart begged Obama to do something, maybe like FDR. His reponse was that everybody is struggling.

We're done, finished, over.....

Hey - a full-body scanner would've immediately found this guy out.

If not, the latest in patdown techniques would've surely detected something amiss.

In the middle of the 19th century, Afghanistan looked like a prize to be added to the Raj, so the British dispatched an Expeditionary Force. That BEF never returned. Graveyard of Empires. British Empire RIP.

But, if one continues reading, Britain continued to look at the Afghanistan problem: they wanted the raids on the Raj and the threat of Russian encroachment stopped. So the Second British-Afghan War installed a member of the Afghani royalty as king, and he brought stability to the region. Afghanistan remained an independent nation, not part of the Raj, and not even a British neo-colony. But the Afghani raids on the Raj stopped until '47, when the Raj was dissolved, and Russian encroachment was stopped for almost a century. So victory for the British, if one takes the right definition of victory.

***

When the Soviets marched into Afghanistan, the right-wing Times columnists mourned that the US had elected a loser who had finally, irrevocably lost the Great Game.

But then, after 9 years, the Afghan forces did not march triumphantly into Moscow, so it wasn't a clear defeat for the USSR, it was just a realisation the the word for 'victory' was pronounced 'da svidanya.'

But when the costs of the Soviet Afghan adventure were tallied, they proved to be more than the USSR could afford, so the USSR completely disintegrated. Graveyard of Empires. USSR RIP.

***

Meanwhile, the fact that the British were taken in by the latest fraud means that they seem to have lost whatever expertise they once had about the region.

But the war is squandering a lot of money. So much that, when yesterday's Times article said that the fraudster was paid 'a lot of money,' I thought they meant serious money. Today, Ms. Dowd says it was only in the low six figures, an amount lost in the round-off error.

Still, trillions are being squandered (admittedly, an much smaller fraction of the total US economy compared with the fraction of their economy that the Soviets squandered), and that money is ending up in some pockets somewhere.

So, from the point of view of the decision makers who are continuing the war, it's not at all stupid, it's just profitable.
Add this to the growing list of reasons to get out of Afghanistan as soon as possible.
